items.item_details: Education Code Section 72122 provides that student disciplinary matters be considered by the Board of Trustees in closed session unless the student submits a written request to the Board Secretary that the hearing of the governing board be held as a public meeting.  As of the time of posting the agenda, no such request had been received; however, the deadline for submission of the request had not yet passed.

De Anza College:
	 
Cecilia Hui - Librarian
Zachary Judson, Mathematics
Julie Lewis, Intercultural Studies
James Mailhot, Mathematics
Ravjeet Singh, Economics
Danny Tran, Mathematics
	 
Foothill College:
	 
Zachary Cembellin, Mathematics
Hilda Fernandez, English
Kathryn Maurer, Anthropology
Sandhya Rao, Chemistry
Teresa Zwack, Mathematics
	 
*Advancement in the tenure process is contingent upon having met all requirements including having served a complete probationary contract year. A probationary faculty employee is deemed to have completed a probationary contract year if he or she provides service for 75 percent of the academic year. If the probationary faculty employee serves less than 75 percent of an academic year, the year shall be considered a “prob zero” year and shall not count for tenure. In such cases the tenure process is interrupted by the prob zero year and shall be resumed in the subsequent academic year in which the faculty employee is able to perform services for 75 percent of the academic year.
	 
Submitted by:
  Dorene Novotny, Vice Chancellor of Human Resources & Equal Opportunity, x6211
Additional contact names:
  N/A

  Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Revised board policy 3200 (formerly 2510) regarding accreditation was presented for first reading on February 9, 2015. Revisions to the policy include the addition of language from the accreditation standards that ensures the governing board is kept informed regarding accreditation matters and a change to the policy number to align with the Community College League of California Policy and Procedure Service numbering system. Added language is indicated on the attachment by bold, underlined text, and deleted text is indicated by strikethrough. 
	 
The policy revisions were approved by the Academic and Professional Matters Committee on October 24, 2014, and by the Chancellor's Advisory Council on January 16, 2015. 
	 
References:
Accreditation Eligibility Requirement 21
Accreditation Standards I.C.12 and 13 (formerly IV.B.1.i)
Title 5, Section 51016
	 
Submitted by:
Linda Thor
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
					Yes
items.item_recommendation: Chancellor Thor recommends that the Board of Trustees adopt revised board policy 3200 Accreditation.
items.item_text: Board Policy 3200 (formerly 2510) Accreditation - Revised (Second Reading)
items.item_text_raw: 1) Board Policy 3200 (formerly 2510) Accreditation - Revised (Second Reading)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Revised board policy 3250 (formerly 3050) regarding institutional planning was presented for first reading on February 9, 2015. The policy has been revised to delineate plans required by state regulations, add language from accreditation standards, change the policy number to align with the Community College League of California Policy and Procedure Service numbering system, and update legal references. Added language is indicated on the attachment by bold, underlined text, and deleted text is indicated by strikethrough. 
	 
The policy revisions were approved by the Academic and Professional Matters Committee on October 24, 2014, and by the Chancellor's Advisory Council on January 16, 2015. 
	 
References:
Accreditation Standards I.B.9, III.B.4, III.C.2, III.D.2, IV.B.3, and IV.D.5 (formerly I.B)
Title 5, Sections 51008, 51010, 51027, 53003, 54220, 55080, 55190, 55250, 55510, and 56270 et seq.
	 
Submitted by:
Linda Thor
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Chancellor Thor recommends that the Board of Trustees adopt revised board policy 3250 Institutional Planning.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
In accordance with Education Code 87469, a probationary faculty employee must serve at least 75% service of a full-time assignment for the academic year for the year to be counted as a year of service as a probationary employee. Further, in accordance with Education Code 87776 time spent on any unpaid leave of absence shall not be included in computing the service required as a prerequisite to attainment of, or eligibility for, tenure.
	 
The following probationary faculty employee shall be re-employed as follows:
	 
Re-employment of Second-Year Faculty (Phase II) 2014-2015 to Second-Year (Phase II) 2015-2016 Academic Year*
	 
Foothill College
Rosa Nguyen - Chemistry

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The district's Occupational Training Institute (OTI) will provide an array of education, training and job placement services for CalWORKs clients. Foothill-De Anza Community College District will provide site liaisons at designated campuses. Site liaisons will work collaboratively with CalWORKs staff and each other to enroll students in the first class opening and minimize time on wait lists. Site Liaisons will provide supportive services, family stabilization services, case tracking and client progress reporting an accordance with CalWORKs employment services rules and regulations. The total amount of this contract will not exceed $147,817.00 in grant funding.
	 
Board approval is requested for the renewal of this CalWORKs liaison contract for the 2015-16 year.
	 
Submitted by:
De Anza President, Brian Murphy, ext. 8705
Additional contact names:
De Anza VP Student Services. Stacey Cook ext. 8330. OTI Supervisor, Dan Dishno, ext. 8307
Is backup provided?
Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The District was successful at the election on June 6, 2006, in obtaining authorization from the District's voters to issue up to $490,800,000 aggregate principal amount of the District's general obligation bonds (“Measure C”). The election was conducted under Proposition 39, which was chaptered as the Strict Accountability in Local School Construction Bonds Act of 2000. Among the accountability requirements the District must comply with is the establishment of a Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee whose duties and responsibilities are set forth in bylaws as shown on the Measure C website at http://www.measurec.fhda.edu/. The duties include the development of an Annual Report which shall be presented to the Board of Trustees in public session. The report is required to address the following:
A statement indicating whether the District is in compliance with the requirements of Article XIIIA, Section 1(b)(3) of the California Constitution; and,
A summary of the Committee’s proceedings and activities for the preceding year.
The annual report for 2013/2014 will be presented by Mr. Dudley Andersen, Chairperson of the Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee, and can be viewed at http://measurec.fhda.edu/AR1314/Print-friendly.pdf
	 
Submitted by:
Steven Kitchen, Executive Director, Facilities and Operations, extension 6150
Additional contact names:
Kevin McElroy, Vice Chancellor, Business Services, extension 6201
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Executive Director of Facilities and Operations Steven Kitchen recommends that the Board accept the report.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The artificial turf on Foothill College’s football field was installed 10 years ago, and has reached the end of its useful life. The average life cycle for artificial turf is 8-10 years. The District selected the FieldTurf product based on information provided by Foothill College staff, plant services staff, and the District’s landscape architect. FieldTurf also offers a variety of alternative infill systems.   
	 
In addition to Foothill College's football field, both colleges are expected to replace existing artificial turf fields during the next two years. Because the estimated cost of the field turf projects will exceed the current statutory bid threshold of $86,000, the District must either conduct its own bidding and award process or obtain board authorization to utilize existing contracts awarded by other public entities. This process is commonly known as “piggybacking”. The competitively bid California Multiple Award Schedule (CMAS) contract with FieldTurf USA Inc. is available and it includes the items required by the colleges. 
	 
It is highly unlikely that a separate bid process conducted by our District would result in more favorable prices, terms, and conditions than offered on the CMAS contract for the same goods and services. The CMAS contract establishes discounts for artificial turf inclusive of specification development services, shipping and delivery costs, 8-year warranty, and installation services.
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Steve Kitchen, Bernata Slater, Annette Perez
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services recommends the Board of Trustees make a finding that it is in the best interest of the District to issue purchase orders for artificial turf and related services in excess of the legally mandated bid threshold pursuant to Public Contract Code 20652 and the California Multiple Award Schedule #4-06-78-0031A.
items.item_text: Authorize the use of California Multiple Award Schedule (CMAS) contract to purchase artificial turf and related services from FieldTurf USA Inc. pursuant to Public Contract Code 20652 (ACTION)
items.item_text_raw: 16) Authorize the use of California Multiple Award Schedule (CMAS) contract to purchase artificial turf and related services from FieldTurf USA Inc. pursuant to Public Contract Code 20652 (ACTION)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The Initial Study/Proposed Mitigated Negative Declaration for the proposed Measure C project 404, New District Offices (State Clearinghouse Number: 2015012009) was circulated for 30-day public and agency review by the Office of Planning and Research (OPR) State Clearinghouse from January 6, 2015, to February 5, 2015.  The public review period provided the opportunity for the public and agencies to review the issues addressed and to offer comments on any aspect of the process, and/or the adequacy of the evaluation and mitigation measures.  The Notice of Intent (NOI) to adopt the Mitigated Negative Declaration was sent to the State Clearinghouse; posted on the project site; and sent to interested local agencies and parties in accordance with Section 21091 of the State of California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) Guidelines.
	 
The District received two written comment letters on the Initial Study/Mitigated Negative Declaration:
·      Santa Clara Valley Water District (Date: February 4, 2015)
·      Los Altos Hills, California (Date: February 3, 2015)
	 
In addition, the District received a confirmation letter from the State Clearinghouse after the close of the public review period acknowledging that the District has complied with the State Clearinghouse requirements for draft environmental documents pursuant to CEQA.
	 
The Draft Initial Study/Proposed Mitigated Negative Declaration together with the Mitigation Monitoring and Reporting Program and response to comments constitute the Final Mitigated Negative Declaration that will be considered for adoption by the Board of Trustees. 
	 
Submitted by:
Steve Kitchen, Executive Director, Facilities and Operations x6150
Additional contact names:
Art Heinrich, Bond Program Director x 6295
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Executive Director Kitchen recommends adoption of the resolution to approve the proposed project and to adopt the Mitigated Negative Declaration and Mitigation Monitoring Program for the proposed New District Offices Located in Los Altos Hills, California.
items.item_text: New District Offices – California Environmental Quality Act Initial Study/Mitigated Negative Declaration (ACTION)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Title:  Prime Contract Change Order 3
Vendor:  DL Falk Construction
Agreement Date:  August 4, 2014
Campus:  De Anza College
Project Number:  216
Project Name:  Library
Amount:  $24,551
For: 
	 
Prime Contract Change Order #03 - revises the original contract sum between the District and D.L. Falk Construction to improve facility performance and maintainability.   
	 
PCO#020 – COR#11.1 RFI#59 Extra Drywall at Bathrooms – Existing conditions had plaster that was 1 ¼” to 1 ½” thick. Required to add additional layer of drywall to make the ADA requirements acceptable.
PCO#021 – COR#16 Elevator Door Controller Upgrade – Remove existing GAL Mod operator controls and install new GAL MOVFRII upgrade package, including new door motor, H900 Simplex elevator controller and adjust and test.
PCO#022 – COR#18 RFI#27 Curb in Restrooms – Concealed field conditions of the existing fixture carrier required concrete demolition, relocation of new carriers, relocation of waste lines, backfill, and installation of concrete.   
	 
Total Change Orders to date represent 9.9% against the original contract amount. Funding is included in the current budget.
	 
Submitted by:
Steve Kitchen, Executive Director, Facilities and Operations
Additional contact names:
Tom Armstrong, Director, Bond Program Management, De Anza College
Donna Jones-Dulin, Associate Vice President, Finance & Educational Resources, De Anza College
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Approval
items.item_text: D.L. Falk Construction - Prime Contract Change Order 3 - Library - $24,551
items.item_text_raw: E) D.L. Falk Construction - Prime Contract Change Order 3 - Library - $24,551

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Parcel C at the former Onizuka Air Force Station in Sunnyvale California was conveyed as a Public Benefit Allowance to Foothill-De Anza Community College District on February 14, 2013.  As required by the deed that conveyed the property, on February 13 an annual utilization report was provided to the Department of Education to demonstrate that the property is being utilized solely for  uses set forth and approved in the terms and conditions of the deed. 
	 
A copy of the report is provided to the Board of Trustees for information.
	 
Submitted by:
Steve Kitchen x6150
Additional contact names:
Art Heinrich x6295
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_text: Annual utilization report for the Education Center at the former Onizuka Air Force Station (INFORMATION)
items.item_text_raw: 20) Annual utilization report for the Education Center at the former Onizuka Air Force Station (INFORMATION)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
On September 10, 2012, the Board of Trustees authorized award of a Preconstruction Services Agreement to C. W. Driver (CWD) as the Lease-Leaseback contractor for the Education Center (Project). The Preconstruction Services Agreement requires CWD to solicit competitive bids to develop a Guaranteed Maximum Price (GMP) for each of three Project phases (demolition, early site work, and building construction). 
	 
On July 1, 2013 the Board of Trustees approved execution of the Site Lease and the Facilities Lease for the Project, which included a GMP for only the Site Demolition Phase of the project; demolition is complete.  On November 3, 2014 the Board of Trustees approved execution of Amendment No.1 to the Facilities Lease, which included a GMP for the Early Site Work Phase of the project.  CWD is currently working on that phase.
	 
This Amendment No. 2 modifies the Facilities Lease to include a GMP for the Building Construction Phase of the Project in the amount of $23,098,148.  This phase includes construction of the Education Center building of approximately 46,000 square feet and its associated parking lots and site work.  This phase of work is scheduled to begin in late March with onsite activities beginning in May.
	 
Submitted by:
 Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Steve Kitchen, Executive Director, Facilities and Operations, Art Heinrich, Director, Bond Program Management, Foothill College
Is backup provided?
 Yes
items.item_recommendation: Authorize Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services, to execute Amendment No. 2 to the Facilities Lease with C. W. Driver, and to accept the GMP in the amount of $23,098,148 for the Building Construction Phase of the Project.
items.item_text: Amendment No. 2 to the Foothill-De Anza Education Center Facilities Lease with C.W. Driver for the Building Construction Phase (ACTION)
items.item_text_raw: 21) Amendment No. 2 to the Foothill-De Anza Education Center Facilities Lease with C.W. Driver for the Building Construction Phase (ACTION)
